unnormalised: Hey guys, planning a train trip in India can be a bit overwhelming, right? Especially when you’re trying to figure out the best route and train number. I’ve been travelling by Indian Railways for years, so thought I’d share some tips. It's definitely an experience!
normalised: Hey guys, planning a train trip in India can be a bit overwhelming, right? Especially when you’re trying to figure out the best route and train number. I’ve been travelling by Indian Railways for years, so thought I’d share some tips. It's definitely an experience!

unnormalised: First off, the IRCTC website is your friend, but also sometimes your foe, haha. It can be a pain to navigate, but it's the official place to book tickets. Try to book well in advance, especially if you’re traveling during peak season like Diwali or summer holidays. Trains like the Rajdhani and Shatabdi are usually pretty good, but they book up fast. I usually aim for at least 2 months beforehand.
normalised: First off, the I-R-C-T-C website is your friend, but also sometimes your foe, ha ha. It can be a pain to navigate, but it's the official place to book tickets. Try to book well in advance, especially if you’re traveling during peak season like Diwali or summer holidays. Trains like the Rajdhani and Shatabdi are usually pretty good, but they book up fast. I usually aim for at least two months beforehand.

unnormalised: Also, keep an eye out for different classes. AC First Class (1A) is the most expensive and comfortable, but 2A and 3A are usually good enough and much cheaper. Sleeper class (SL) is the most basic and can get crowded, but it’s also the most budget-friendly. A sleeper ticket from Delhi to Mumbai will only cost you Rs. 600 or so.
normalised: Also, keep an eye out for different classes. A-C First Class (one A) is the most expensive and comfortable, but two A and three A are usually good enough and much cheaper. Sleeper class (S-L) is the most basic and can get crowded, but it’s also the most budget-friendly. A sleeper ticket from Delhi to Mumbai will only cost you rupee six hundred or so.

unnormalised: Don’t forget to check your PNR status after booking. This will tell you if your ticket is confirmed, in RAC (Reservation Against Cancellation), or on the waiting list. If you’re on the waiting list, there's a chance you won’t get a confirmed seat. Sometimes you get lucky and it gets confirmed last minute! You can check your PNR status on the IRCTC website or through various apps. My last trip from Kolkata, my PNR number was 4567890123 and it got confirmed just 4 hrs before departure!
normalised: Don’t forget to check your P-N-R status after booking. This will tell you if your ticket is confirmed, in R-A-C (Reservation Against Cancellation), or on the waiting list. If you’re on the waiting list, there's a chance you won’t get a confirmed seat. Sometimes you get lucky and it gets confirmed last minute! You can check your P-N-R status on the I-R-C-T-C website or through various apps. My last trip from Kolkata, my P-N-R number was four five six seven eight nine zero one two three and it got confirmed just four hours before departure!

unnormalised: Finally, remember to bring your own food and water, especially on long journeys. While the railways provide catering, it’s not always the best. Also, keep your belongings safe, especially at night. Happy travels, and enjoy the ride! Remember to download a timetable app - that way you can see if your train (say, 12345) is on time!
